section.title: Audience
section.para: SystemStudio is a product intended for system administrators who need to build, test, deploy and maintain Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS-based systems. Certain chapters in this manual assume you have a particular level of knowledge.

For Chapter 3, "Building a System," in addition to knowing how to create and edit XML files, manage a web server and create USB and CD/DVD boot media, you should have an intermediate skill level with the following components:

listitem.para: Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS installation, usage, system administration and configuration;
RPM package usage; and
YUM usage and configuration.

section.para: For Chapter 4, "Creating a Production Environment," experience with version control systems, local mirror hosting, XPath and XInclude.
For Chapter 5, "Doing More with SystemStudio," key skills include understanding how to automate Anaconda installations using kickstart files and command line arguments.

section.title: What's Not Covered
section.para: This manual complements several SystemStudio documents. The "Installation Instructions" and "Getting Started Guide" provide basic information about obtaining and installing SystemStudio and creating a basic CentOS system distribution. The "System Definition File Reference" (SDFR) contains the syntax for system definition elements and attributes. Finally, SystemStudio has a set of man pages explaining the systemstudio command, its options and the SystemStudio configuration file, systemstudio.conf. This manual contains references to all four throughout the text.
These SystemStudio documents are available at the Rendition Software website.

section.title: How to Read
section.para: The intent of the manual is to help you use SystemStudio effectively to build and maintain system distributions, and to use system distributions to install and update client machines. This manual takes a top-down approach, explaining the concepts before giving steps, commands and code examples that you can use to build, deploy and enhance your own system distributions.

section.title: Conventions Used
section.para: The document conventions are alphabetically listed below.

listitem.para: The Caution tag flags issues of importance.

caution.para: Using the 'dd' command to copy the diskboot.img file onto a USB key will destroy existing data on the device.

listitem.para: Command names in SystemStudio or function names in other programs appear throughout the document.

Elements and attributes in XML are referred to by their XPath equivalents. The active node is always considered to be the root, system; thus, the first element in the XPath expression is the top-level element, while subsequent elements/attributes are its children. Top-level elements in the SDFR and their child elements use the parent/child/child format, while @attribute-names are preceded by an @ symbol. The assumed parent element is system. For more details on XPath syntax, see XML Path Language.

section.title: Organization
section.para: This manual contains five chapters, each with an increasing level of complexity and detail.

listitem.para: Chapter I, "Preface," provides information about how to use and read this manual. It also contains information on obtaining the SystemStudio product.

Chapter 2, "Introduction" explains what a system distribution is, how SystemStudio helps you build one in an efficient timely manner and the underlying architecture that makes this improved performance possible. The section also includes a "Glossary of Terms" explaining terms used within the SystemStudio realm.

Chapter 3, "Building a System," covers the basic concepts for configuring the SystemStudio build machine, defining and deploying a system distribution, running SystemStudio and updating a system distribution. As a use case model, these sections will help you create a basic Samba server distribution based on CentOS 5.

Chapter 4, "Creating a Production Environment," will help you set up a managed development and deployment environment using SystemStudio as its cornerstone. It explains implementing the development - staging - production environment within the context of SystemStudio. The Samba server system distribution you created in Part I will have new feature requirements to implement in Part II.

Chapter 4 also discusses how SystemStudio makes your life easier as a system or build administrator. Versioning system files and utilizing an object-oriented model through the XInclude mechanism for the system distribution definitions are important usability features. Choosing the best location for storing and downloading a system distribution via the web is another key concept.

Chapter 5, "Doing More with SystemStudio" will help you customize your system distributions. It describes using kickstart files to automate client installation, discusses GPG checking and using GPG keys to sign your own packages, and provides information on creating CD/DVD installation images.
